title: Understanding Arthritis and Inflammation
author: WebMD Editorial Contributors

content: The body's white blood cells and substances that they produce to protect our bodies from infection by foreign organisms, such as bacteria and viruses.

In some inflammatory diseases, however, the body's defense system -- the immune system -- triggers a response when there are no foreign substances to fight off. In these diseases, called autoimmune disorders , the body's normally protective immune system causes damage to its own tissues. The body responds as if normal tissues are infected or somehow abnormal.

content_blocks.text: The body's white blood cells and substances that they produce to protect our bodies from infection by foreign organisms, such as bacteria and viruses.

In some inflammatory diseases, however, the body's defense system -- the immune system -- triggers a response when there are no foreign substances to fight off. In these diseases, called autoimmune disorders , the body's normally protective immune system causes damage to its own tissues. The body responds as if normal tissues are infected or somehow abnormal.

sections.heading: What Diseases Are Associated With Inflammation?
content: Some, but not all, types of arthritis are the result of misdirected inflammation . Arthritis is a general term that describes inflammation in the joints. Some types of arthritis associated with inflammation include the following:

Other painful conditions of the joints and musculoskeletal system that may not be associated with inflammation include osteoarthritis , fibromyalgia , muscular low back pain , and muscular neck pain .
bullets: Rheumatoid arthritis
Psoriatic arthritis
Gouty arthritis

sections.heading: What Are the Symptoms of Inflammation?
content: Inflammation is characterized by:
Often, only a few of these symptoms are present.
Inflammation may also be associated with general " flu -like" symptoms including:
bullets: Redness
Swollen joint that's warm to the touch
Joint pain
Joint stiffness
Loss of joint function
Fever
Chills
Fatigue /loss of energy
Headaches
Loss of appetite
Muscle stiffness

content_blocks.text: Inflammation is characterized by:
associated_bullets: Redness
Swollen joint that's warm to the touch
Joint pain
Joint stiffness
Loss of joint function

content_blocks.text: Often, only a few of these symptoms are present.
Inflammation may also be associated with general " flu -like" symptoms including:

Loss of appetite
Muscle stiffness

sections.heading: What Causes Inflammation and What Are Its Effects?
content: Inflammation occurs when substances from the body's white blood cells are released into the blood or affected tissues to protect your body from foreign invaders. This release of chemicals increases the blood flow to the area of injury or infection, and may result in redness and warmth. Some of the chemicals cause a leak of fluid into the tissues, resulting in swelling. This protective process may stimulate nerves and cause pain .
The increased number of cells and inflammatory substances within the joint cause irritation, swelling of the joint lining, and eventual wearing down of cartilage (cushions at the end of bones).

content_blocks.text: Inflammation occurs when substances from the body's white blood cells are released into the blood or affected tissues to protect your body from foreign invaders. This release of chemicals increases the blood flow to the area of injury or infection, and may result in redness and warmth. Some of the chemicals cause a leak of fluid into the tissues, resulting in swelling. This protective process may stimulate nerves and cause pain .
The increased number of cells and inflammatory substances within the joint cause irritation, swelling of the joint lining, and eventual wearing down of cartilage (cushions at the end of bones).

sections.heading: How Are Inflammatory Diseases Diagnosed?
content: Inflammatory diseases are diagnosed after careful evaluation of the following:
bullets: Complete medical history and physical exam with attention to the location of painful joints
Presence of joint stiffness in the morning
Evaluation of accompanying symptoms and signs
Results of X-rays and laboratory tests

sections.heading: Can Inflammation Affect Internal Organs?
content: Yes. Inflammation can affect organs as part of an autoimmune disorder. The type of symptoms experienced depends on which organs are affected. For example:

Pain may not be a primary symptom of an inflammatory disease, because many organs do not have pain-sensitive nerves. Treatment of organ inflammation is directed at the cause of inflammation whenever possible.
bullets: Inflammation of the heart ( myocarditis ) may cause shortness of breath or fluid retention.
Inflammation of the small tubes that transport air to the lungs may cause shortness of breath.
Inflammation of the kidneys (nephritis) may cause high blood pressure or kidney failure .

sections.heading: How Are Inflammatory Joint Diseases Treated?
content: There are a number of treatment options for inflammatory diseases including medications , rest, exercise , and surgery to correct joint damage . The type of treatment prescribed will depend on several factors, including the type of disease, the person's age, type of medications they are taking, overall health, medical history, and severity of symptoms.

content_blocks.text: There are a number of treatment options for inflammatory diseases including medications , rest, exercise , and surgery to correct joint damage . The type of treatment prescribed will depend on several factors, including the type of disease, the person's age, type of medications they are taking, overall health, medical history, and severity of symptoms.

content: The goals of treatment are the following:
bullets: Correct, control, or slow down the underlying disease process
Avoid or modify activities that aggravate pain
Relieve pain through pain medications and anti-inflammatory drugs
Maintain joint movement and muscle strength through physical therapy
Decrease stress on the joints by using braces, splints, or canes as needed

content_blocks.text: The goals of treatment are the following:
associated_bullets: Correct, control, or slow down the underlying disease process
Avoid or modify activities that aggravate pain
Relieve pain through pain medications and anti-inflammatory drugs
Maintain joint movement and muscle strength through physical therapy
Decrease stress on the joints by using braces, splints, or canes as needed

sections.heading: What Drugs Are Used to Treat Inflammatory Diseases?
content: There are many drugs available to decrease joint pain, swelling, and inflammation, and possibly prevent or minimize the progression of the inflammatory disease. The medications include the following:

Some of these medications are traditionally used to treat other conditions such as cancer or inflammatory bowel disease , or to reduce the risk of rejection of a transplanted organ. However, when " chemotherapy " drugs (such as methotrexate or cyclophosphamide) are used to treat inflammatory diseases, the doses are significantly lower and the risks of side effects tend to be less than when prescribed in higher doses for cancer treatment .
When you are prescribed any medication, it is important to meet with your doctor regularly so they can detect the development of any side effects.
bullets: Nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs ( NSAIDs , such as aspirin, ibuprofen or naproxen)
Corticosteroids (such as prednisone)
Antimalarial medications (such as hydroxychloroquine)
Other oral drugs, including apremilast ( Otezla ), azathioprine (Imuran), cyclophosphamide (Cytoxan), leflunomide (Arava), methotrexate , and sulfasalazine

Biologic drugs such as abatacept, adalimumab (Humira), certolizumab (Cimzia), etanercept (Enbrel), enercept-szzs (Ereizi), golimumab (Simponi, Simponi Aria), infliximab (Remicade), rituximab (Rituxin), and tocilizumab (Actemra).

meta_description: WebMD explains the role of inflammation in arthritis and other autoimmune diseases.
